newsitem.title: USA: Bristol-Myers get new label for Pravachol.
newsitem.headline: Bristol-Myers get new label for Pravachol.

text.p: Bristo-Myers Squibb Co said Thursday that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has cleared new labeling for its cholesterol-lowering drug Pravachol, eliminating the recommendation for liver function testing at six weeks and for semiannual testing in patients with normal test results at 12 weeks.
For patients taking Pravachol, it is recommended that liver function testing be performed prior to, and at 12 weeks following initiation of therapy or the elevation of dose.
Testing after 12 weeks would need to be performed if there is an abnormal test result or signs and symptoms of liver disease.

According to Bristol-Myers, for all other drugs in Pravachol's class, liver function testing is recommended prior to, and then at six and 12 weeks after the initiation of therapy or an elevation in dose, and periodically thereafter.
Pravachol is the only one to receive clearance from the FDA for less frequent liver function testing, the company said.
